summary: Parents rehearse tough conversations with a realistic virtual child before trying at home.
overview: BRAT (Boundary, Respect & Affection Training) is a multi-agent LLM system designed to help parents in family therapy rehearse challenging conversations with a realistic virtual 'child' before attempting them at home. Developed as part of an IRB-approved research study, BRAT provides a safe, controlled environment for parents to practice difficult interactions and build confidence in their communication skills.
myRole: As the technical and product design lead, I architected the multi-agent system, designed the conversation flows, and established the integration with Azure/OpenAI services. I worked closely with clinical researchers to ensure the system met IRB requirements and clinical standards. I also implemented the Whisper ASR integration for voice interaction, designed the RAG system for context-aware responses, and integrated Qualtrics for research data collection and analysis.
outcomes: Successfully deployed in IRB-approved research study with active parent participants
Achieved realistic, context-aware dialogue generation that clinicians validated as therapeutically appropriate
Built robust safety constraints and content filtering to ensure research-grade reliability
Integrated voice interaction capabilities for more natural parent-child conversation simulation
Established scalable architecture that can be adapted for other therapeutic contexts
